label: [Ruthie Wright et al. case]: Letter from Thos Ryan, First Assistant Secretary of the Interior to the Commissioner to the Five Civilized Tribes, Muskogee, Indian Territory, January 26, 1906 [5 copies]

metadata.label: title
metadata.value: [Ruthie Wright et al. case]: Letter from Thos Ryan, First Assistant Secretary of the Interior to the Commissioner to the Five Civilized Tribes, Muskogee, Indian Territory, January 26, 1906 [5 copies]

metadata.label: abstract
metadata.value: In a letter to the Commissioner to the Five Civilized Tribes, Thomas Ryan, the First Assistant Secretary to the Interior, explains the Department's decision to deny a motion to reopen the case of Ruthie Wright et al. for enrollment as Cherokee Freedmen. The Department had previously approved the Commissioner's decision to deny their application, concurring with the conclusion that the applicants were not entitled to the benefits of the treaty of 1866. The motion to reopen this case was denied after the Department found evidence that contradicted Ruthie Wright's claim to have been a "free" person living in the Nation at the start of the Civil War. Instead, she was found to have escaped from Mary Ann Bright, her enslaver at the time, from Fort Smith, Arkansas to the Cherokee Nation, and had lived there as a free person ever since.

The motion to reopen this case was denied after the Department found evidence that contradicted Ruthie Wright's claim to have been a "free" person living in the Nation at the start of the Civil War.
